position.marginalia_text: eius humiditas vertitur in siccitate[m]. et sic fit transitus ad medicina[m] disponente[m], qua[e] est caliditas et siccitas, qua[e] d[icitu]r Latitudo. Natura tame[n] a frigido et humido frigiditate[m], et a calido et sicco siccitatem recipit, et fit terra. Postea vero per calore[m] excedente[m] caliditate[m] qua[e] rema[n]sit in corpore[m] fit transitus ad co[n]trariu[m], destruendo frigidate[m], et introducendo caliditate[m], qua[e] dispositio dicitur profundu[m], seu occultum corporis. et hoc optime patet in libro perfecti magisterij in particula illa: Ferrum in sua altitudo est frigidum humidu[m], caldium siccu[m], cholericu[m], rubeum, acutum, odoriferum, masculinu[m], et cetera. Viso demu[m], qualiter Argentu[m] viuu[m] transubstatiatur de natura natura[m], s[cilicet] de frigiditato et humiditate in caliditate[m] et siccitate[m]. Et quia in isto puncto, maior pars philosophoru[m] incipit loqui: vt Alphidius de minera: sulfur rubeum dixit. Notetis quod minera huius operis est sulphur rubeum: et secundu[m] Luca[m], Masculinu[m], cum dicit, Accipite Marthek et dealbate enim, [etc] Masculu[m] eni[m] pro mulgavit: et plures alij sapientes possent addico in dande[m] sente[n]tia: quos in pra[e]sentia ommittimus brevitatis gratia Ratio aute[m] quare o[mn]es ferè initium sump[er]sernit ab isto corpore rubeo, est quia istud corpus rubeum est principiu[m] totius tinctura[e], Nex fit tinctura vera sine eo. Vnde Rosinus inquit, Sciatis quod no[n] fuit [etc]

book.title: The Height of the Perfection of Mastery

marginalia.translation: [And its] humidity turns into dryness. And thus it is made transition into the prescribed medicine, which is heat and dryness, which is called width. Nevertheless, nature receives cold from the cold and humid and driness from the cold and dry and soil is made. But afterwards, through heat exceeding from the heat, which had remained in the body, the transition happens to the contrary, by destroying the cold and introducing the heat which is called disposition or the secret of the body. And this is best accessible in the book The Height of the Perfection of Mastery in this short passage: Iron in its height is cold humid, hot dry, choleric, red, sharp, fragrant, masculine etc.
